When New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio came into office in 2013, he pledged to make schools safer, fairer, and more transparent. As his time in office nears its end, we examine de Blasio's successes, failures, and what has to happen next in our latest commentary piece.

Plus, the backlash against racial justice comes to New York schools, and x gender markers will finally be available on state IDs.

De Blasio's education legacy

De Blasio pledged to chart a different path on education from his predecessor, Mike Bloomberg, who presided over soaring suspensions. But while he did accomplish some important victories, de Blasio never successfully addressed the disparities between who gets punished in City schools and who gets a second chance.

In our piece, we explore what needs to happen to reduce and ultimately eliminate police from schools while giving schools the resources they need to be safe and welcoming.

Racial justice backlash in NY schools

States across the country have introduced or passed legislation banning the discussion of race or racism in schools. In New York, we've received reports of police officers and their unions trying to control what students learn. We take a look at what this backlash to racial justice is really about and what schools can do to combat it.

X gender markers come to NY IDs

Identity documents are required to participate in society. Yet, for too long, transgender New Yorkers have had to run a gauntlet to get accurate identification, while nonbinary people have not been able to get IDs that reflect who they are. We dissect a new state law that will change all this.
